document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the tingine genera Cysteochila, Hurdchila, Physatocheila, and Xynotingis from Japan, with description of a new genus (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Tingidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the tingine genera Cysteochila, Hurdchila, Physatocheila, and Xynotingis from Japan, with description of a new genus (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Tingidae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Entomological Laboratory, Graduate School of Bioresource and Bioenvironmental Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan. kodokusignal @ gmail. com; https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0002 - 2238 - 5015 & Research Fellowship for Young Scientists (DC 1), Japan Society for the Promotion of Science, Tokyo, Japan
Laboratory of Entomology, Faculty of Agriculture, Tokyo University of Agriculture, Kanagawa, Japan.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Cysteochila abundantis
Drake & Poor, 1937a: 8
. Holotype : macropterous ♂ , Philippines : Mindanao , Bukidnon Province , Tang- kulan; USNM.

Cysteochila abundans
[incorrect subsequent spelling]:
Drake & Ruhoff (1965a: 164)
(catalog).

. A single specimen deposited in ELKU is labeled “
Cysteochila hidakai Takeya, 1962
” (manuscript name).

Diagnosis. Recognized among other species of
Cysteochila
by a combination of the following characters: general color ashen ( Fig. 1A–E ); median spine on head reaching level far remote from bases of frontal spines; rostrum reaching posterior margin of mesosternum; lateral carinae of pronotum nearly parallel to each other in anterior part, concealed by paranotum in anterior part; paranotum incompletely covering pronotal disc in anterior part, not touching each other, not concealing median carina of pronotum, widened posteriorly; outer margin of paranotum gently curved outward in its entire length; anterior margin of hemelytron nearly straight in its entire length; costal area narrower than subcostal area at widest part, with a single row of areolae in its entire length; and subcostal area with 2 rows of areolae in its entire length.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Habitus images of
Cysteochila abundantis
from Japan. Dried specimen, dorsal and lateral views (A, B). Ventral structures: rostrum (C), male terminalia (D) and female terminalia (E). Scale bars: A, B, 1.0 mm; C–E, 0.2 mm.

FIGURE 2. A living adult (A) of
Cysteochila abundantis
from Ishigaki Island, the Ryukyu Islands, Japan (photographed indoors). Host plant (B,
Cinnamomum yabunikkei H.Ohba
; C,
Toddalia asiatica
(L.) Lam.) of
C . abundantis
on Miyako Island, the Ryukyu Islands, Japan.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. The above-recorded specimens match well with the photographs of the holotype (http://n 2t .net/ ark:/65665/3bd050830-c134-4d8d-adae-4bbe5d36e029) and the original description ( Drake & Poor 1937a ) of
C. abundantis
described from the Philippines .

Cysteochila abundantis
closely resembles
C. tingoides
in the shape of the pronotum but can be easily distinguished from it by the following characteristics: rostrum reaching posterior margin of mesosternum ( Fig. 1C ); anterior margin of hemelytron nearly straight in its entire length ( Fig. 1A ); and costal area with a single row of areolae in its entire length. In contrast,
C. tingoides
presents the following characteristics: rostrum reaching middle part of mesosternum ( Fig. 3C ); anterior margin of hemelytron nearly straight in basal half and curved inward in apical half ( Fig. 3A ); and costal area with 2 rows of areolae in basal part and a single row in remaining parts.

Distribution. Japan (Ryukyu Islands: Okinawa Island, Miyako Island, Ogami Island, Kurima Island, Irabu Island, Ishigaki Island, Iriomote Island, Yonaguni Island), Philippines (Mindanao Island, Luzon Island).

Cysteochila abundantis
is here recorded from Japan for the first time. The discovery of
C . abundantis
from the Okinawa Island represents the northernmost distributional record of this species.

Host plant. Masami Hayashi, Hiroaki Kojima, and the first author of the present paper have confirmed
Antidesma pentandrum (Blanco) Merr.
( Euphorbiaceae ),
Calophyllum inophyllum
L. ( Clusiaceae ),
Cinnamomum yabunikkei H.Ohba
( Lauraceae ) ( Fig. 2B ), and
Toddalia asiatica
(L.) Lam. ( Rutaceae ) ( Fig. 2C ) as the host plants of
C. abundantis
.

Biology. A number of
C. abundantis
individuals were collected from the leaves of the above-mentioned host plants in four botanical families, suggesting that this species is folivorous, similar to many other tingids ( Schuh & Weirauch 2020 ) and euryphagous.
In Japan , adults were observed in almost all seasons (present study).
